uh they support two p two types of
constraint PBD and XPBD.
Um PBD is faster and more game targeted
while XPBD is more expensive per
iteration but it provides more
physically meaningful parameters and it
give artists more control. I've listed
their main differences here and there
are a few things I want to highlight.
First the unit of stiffness are

and one and XPBD on the other hand uses
newton per cm in in Unreal. Uh and when
using XPBD the stretch stiffness is
usually much higher than the bending

Uh while the stretch stiffness can

Another thing about XPBD is we uh also

Um and XPBD also supports anotropic

Uh there are also two types of bending

the neighboring triangles while the

actual angular changes. Um generally
speaking the hinge angle is better at

the whole structure. Uh but it's also uh

very interesting for representing
different materials which is the
buckling stiffness and the buckling re
ratio. These two parameters help control
how fabric folds and wrinkles. Uh when
two neighboring triangles bend beyond a
certain threshold, the solver switches
from using the normal bending to the
buckling bending stiffness. And with a
lower buckling stiffness, the fabric
tends to collapse more easily and stay
in a folded or buckled state.
You can see the effect of buckling in

like silk, I usually go with a higher
ratio and a lower buckling stiffness.
But for fabrics like leather, it's

a relatively higher buckling stiffness.

Okay, let's move on to the uh second
topic today. Runtime stability. This is
important because um as we all know in
most game scenarios clause has to meet
the frame time budget first make sure it
uh stays stable during uh game play and
only after that we aim for realism.
I think the most important issue we face
at runtime is clipping. It usually
happens when characters move quickly.
the collision body moves too far within
a single frame and the penetration can't
be resolved in time. Ultimately, as you
probably know, uh we need more substeps
to solve that. But to be honest, in most
game scenarios, we just don't have
enough budget for that. So the question
people cares more about is
how do you prevent clipping at a low
budget? Um one of the most useful tool
here is the back stop. What it does is
it places a sphere behind each vortex
based on its skinned position and limit
how far each vortex can go back backward
along the normal. Uh it's a per vortex
spatial clamp, not real physical
collision. So relatively it's quite
cheap and stable in terms of
performance.
One thing I want to stress about the
settings here is the back stop radius.
Since it's a per vortex clamp, the
stopping only happens around each uh
around its own sphere. So you need to
make sure the radius is large enough.
Otherwise, it might get around very
easily. In general, the further the back
stop distance, the larger the back stop
radius should be. And you often need to
paint these values based on how loose or
tight uh different parts of your cloth
are.
And there's another issue I want to
mention. Back stop is perfect for tight
outfits, but for um baggy outfits like
the skirt here, because the skinned
ending mesh is quite far from the actual
leg, uh using the skinned position to
block movement can sometimes looks
unnatural. Um it might feels like
there's something invisible behind it.
What I usually do in these cases is
adjust the back stop distance based on
character's movement or speed. So it
only kicks in during fast motion uh when
the clipping is more likely to happen
and those artifacts are less noticeable.
And here you can see with the help of
backs stop I was able to get the cloth
working without clipping even at just
two or one substeps.
Another issue I want to talk about
regarding runtime stability is the
overly stretchy look. It's also a common

that the constraint network can cannot
fully converge or the constraint are
only partially satisfied without enough
iteration. And the denser your sim mesh
is, the worse the situation gets.
They usually deal with this using the

it also has a long tether that connects

which help prevent the cloth from
